raise.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to move or lift something to a higher position, place, or level
raise.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Can you raise the lamp so I can see?
William raised his hat and smiled at her.
Raise your hand if you know the right answer.
raise.translation[0].definitions[0].note: In everyday British English, people usually say lift something up rather than raise something:
Can you lift up the lamp a bit?
Put your hand up if you know the right answer.
British English speakers usually say put up your hand rather than raise your hand:
Put your hand up if you know the right answer.
raise.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: to increase an amount, number, or level
raise.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: Many shops have raised their prices.
The university is working to raise the number of students from state schools.
a campaign to raise awareness of meningitis
Dr Hayward intends to raise the museum’s profile (=make it more well-known).
raise.translation[0].definitions[1].note: In everyday British English, people usually say put up an amount, a price etc rather than raise it:
They’ve put the price of fuel up again.
raise.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: to collect money that you can use to do a particular job or help people
raise.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: The Trust hopes to raise $1 million to buy land.
They are raising funds to help needy youngsters.
a concert to raise money for charity
raise.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: to improve the quality or standard of something
raise.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: Changing the law cannot raise standards.
The team need to raise their game.
raise.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: to begin to talk or write about a subject that you want to be considered or a question that you think should be answered
raise.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: He did not raise the subject again.
I’d like to raise the issue of publicity.
Betty raised the important question of who will be in charge.
raise.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: to cause a particular emotion or reaction
raise.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: This attack raises fears of increased violence against foreigners.
The way the research was carried out raises doubts about the results.
raise.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: to move your eyes, head, or face so that you are looking up
raise.translation[0].definitions[6].exam: Albert raised his eyes and stared at Ruth.
‘No, ’ he said without raising his head.
raise.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: to move or lift yourself into an upright position
raise.translation[0].definitions[7].exam: Adele raised herself from the pillows.
He raised himself up on one elbow to watch.
raise.translation[0].definitions[8].defi: to look after your children and help them grow
raise.translation[0].definitions[8].exam: Stan’s dad died, leaving his mother to raise three sons alone.
It was time for Dean to settle down and raise a family.
Anne married a Jew, despite being raised a Catholic.
The new generation was the first to be raised on processed food.
Camus was born and raised in Algeria.
raise.translation[0].definitions[9].defi: to look after animals or grow plants so that they can be sold or used as food
raise.translation[0].definitions[9].exam: He raised cattle in Nebraska when he was young.
raise.translation[0].definitions[10].def: to collect together a large group of people, especially soldiers
raise.translation[0].definitions[10].exa: The rebels quickly raised an army.
raise.translation[0].definitions[11].def: to make a higher bid than an opponent in a card game
raise.translation[0].definitions[12].def: to speak to someone on a piece of radio equipment
raise.translation[0].definitions[12].exa: They finally managed to raise him at Miller’s sheep farm.
raise.translation[0].definitions[13].def: to wake someone who is difficult to wake
raise.translation[0].definitions[13].exa: Try as he might he could not raise her.
raise.translation[0].definitions[14].def: to make someone who has died live again
raise.translation[0].definitions[14].exa: Jesus raised Lazarus from the grave.
raise.translation[0].definitions[15].def: to build something such as a monument
raise.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: an increase in the money you earn
raise.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: to increase an amount, number, or level
raise.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: We can cut the state budget or raise taxes.
The bank raised interest rates to 15%.
raise.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: to make people consider a question etc, for example by beginning to talk or write about it
raise.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: I tried to raise several points at the meeting.
The Guinness affair raised the question of abolishing trial by jury in complicated fraud cases.
raise.translation[2].definitions[2].defi: to collect the money, capital etc that is needed to do something
raise.translation[2].definitions[2].exam: Hammond Co. will need to raise $2 million to finance the offer.
raise.translation[2].definitions[3].defi: to succeed in getting a loan or mortgage
raise.translation[2].definitions[3].exam: He raised a loan of $20 million from commercial banks.
raise.translation[2].definitions[4].defi: to write out or print out an INVOICE (=document stating how much has to be paid for work or goods), or to ask someone to do this
raise.translation[2].definitions[4].exam: Where goods move between VAT registered traders, a tax invoice has to be raised.
raise.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: an increase in the money you earn
raise.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: The Senate voted itself a 23% pay raise.
